Your Thursday Evening Briefing

Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

Listen to ‘The Daily’

A vaccine breakthrough.

The Modern Love Podcast

The secrets that can end relationships.

Live

Virus and National Security Concerns Grow as Trump Rebuffs Transition

  • President Trump’s refusal to work with President-elect Joe Biden prompted warnings that keeping Mr. Biden in the dark potentially endangers the country.
  • Several top Republicans said the Trump administration should reverse its refusal to grant Mr. Biden access to intelligence briefings. Here’s the latest.

Philadelphia

Ruth Fremson/The New York Times

Washington

Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times

Washington

Oliver Contreras for The New York Times

Columbus, Ohio

Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times

Live Updates

7 minutes ago

  • Virus

    • Fauci urges Americans to ‘double down’ on the basics as virus cases spike.

    • Corey Lewandowski, a Trump campaign adviser, has tested positive for the virus.

  • Economy

    • Democrats demand a big stimulus plan as Republicans insist on targeted relief.

    • WeWork’s revenue fell in the third quarter as office workers stayed home.

  • Disinformation Tracker

    • One America News spreads debunked elections claims.

    • No, the ‘Pallets Full of Ballots’ song is not true.

‘A Black Eye’: Why Political Polling Missed the Mark. Again.

Pollsters are reviewing their latest failures. But is part of the problem the public’s overly high expectations of precision?

Here’s What Will Happen Between Election Day and Inauguration Day

President Trump’s attempts to overturn the election results have made the steps that formalize the will of the people a matter of unusual importance.

No, There Is Not a Lot of Good Evidence Behind the Trump Lawsuits

The evidence the suits have offered has been limited and, according to several judges and experts, unlikely to affect the outcome of the race.

How Pfizer Plans to Distribute Its Vaccine (It’s Complicated)

Success will hinge on an untested network of governments, companies and health workers.

Economic Risks Are High as Chances for Quick Stimulus Narrow

The Federal Reserve chief warned that a vaccine was still too uncertain to count on, and lawmakers signaled that more support was not imminent.

Teenagers in Covid Isolation: ‘I Felt Like I Was Suffocating’

Remote learning, lockdowns and pandemic uncertainty have increased anxiety and depression among adolescents, raising concerns about their mental health.

‘Are We Getting Invaded?’ U.S. Boats Faced Russian Aggression Near Alaska

Russia has escalated its provocative encounters in the North Pacific, harassing boats in U.S. fishing waters and sending bombers toward Alaska’s shores.

Review: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie on Barack Obama’s ‘A Promised Land’

This first volume of the former president’s memoirs brims with warmth, humor and introspection.

The Great Read

Augusta’s Green Jackets: For Winners, Members (and Buyers) Only

The club’s green jackets are not supposed to leave its grounds. A rare few have, becoming an expensive holy grail for memorabilia collectors.

At Home

Keep It Sweet and Simple

A small Thanksgiving meal can be just as festive as a big feast. We have lots of ideas for scaling down your holiday even if it’s just for two.

Start a new Thanksgiving tradition by stir-frying your potatoes.

While 2020 may not have earned them, that doesn’t mean you should forgo sparkling wines this year.

Opinion

Trey Grayson

Republicans Should Be Defending Georgia’s Election Process

The G.O.P. is trying to scapegoat the secretary of state for Trump’s apparent loss there.

Jennifer Senior

Stop Worrying About Biden’s Age. We Need His Wisdom.

There’s a lot to be said right now for a president with loads of experience.

John Thompson Jr.

Let’s Drop the Charade and Pay College Athletes

Gail Collins

Pick the Worst of Trump’s Worst

Nicholas Kristof

When Trump Vandalizes Our Country

Mark Schmitt

Joe Biden Will Face This Overlooked Crisis on Day 1

Spencer Bokat-Lindell

5 Messages Voters Sent in the 2020 Election

Justin Gillis and Michael O’Boyle

When Will Electricity Companies Finally Quit Natural Gas?

Charles M. Blow

Trump’s Election Tantrum

Bruno Maçães

How Trump Almost Broke the Bounds of Reality

The Vatican Report on Clerical Abuse

Editors’ Picks

Why Do Pianists Know So Little About Pianos?

Unlike violinists or trumpeters, piano players rarely get to perform on their own instruments and must be adaptable.

The Answer to What You Should Wear Now (Hint: It’s Not Sweatpants)

The German designer Jil Sander is back, with a new Uniqlo collaboration and a lot of opinions.

A Young Couple Navigate Unexpected Roadblocks to a New Rental

After a few hurdles, this growing family became “the last people to the Brooklyn party.” Which of these Williamsburg options would you choose?

Highlights

  2. Comentario

    La democracia peruana agoniza

    La mayoría de los peruanos se oponía a la destitución del presidente Martín Vizcarra. Sin embargo, un sistema político marcado por componendas y corrupción ha logrado vacarlo a cinco meses de las elecciones poniendo de nuevo al país al borde del caos.

    Hace 42 mPor Alberto Vergara

  1. Comentario

    Joe y la esperanza

    Joe Biden, el presidente electo de Estados Unidos, puede ayudar a mejorar el mundo. No es un héroe ni un revolucionario, pero su plan nos devuelve al camino correcto: nos permite volver a confiar en la razón.

    Hace 10 hBy Diego Fonseca

  2. Salud

  4. Deportes

    Ella escaló El Capitán y estableció un récord

    Emily Harrington es la primera mujer que completa, en menos de 24 horas y en escalada libre, la ruta de Golden Gate hasta El Capitán, un monolito de 914 metros metros de altura en el Parque Nacional Yosemite.

    Hace 10 hBy Marie Fazio

  5. Comentario

    El ominoso silencio de AMLO ante Biden

    El presidente de México y su cancillería han declarado que no reconocerán por el momento al presidente electo de Estados Unidos, Joe Biden. Se trata de un error importante: López Obrador está actuando a partir de su biografía y no como estadista.

    Hace 1 dBy Guillermo Osorno

    Emojis: un lenguaje emocional

    Los emoticonos y su evolución, los emojis, representan el mundo tal y como lo entendemos en 2020.

    8 de noviembre de 2020By Jorge Carrión

    1. Paul Krugman

      Estados Unidos: ¿un Estado fallido?

      Si estuviéramos ante un país extranjero con el nivel de disfunción política de mi país, tal vez consideraríamos que está al borde de convertirse en un Estado cuyo gobierno ya no es capaz de ejercer un control efectivo.

      6 de noviembre de 2020By Paul Krugman

    2. Gaspard Estrada

      Bolsonaro quiere hacerse pasar por Mr. Democracia

      El presidente de Brasil ha dado un giro a su política de confrontación para hacer viable su gobierno. Detrás del juego, se encuentran artimañas ya viejas de la clase política.

      Hace 1 dBy Gaspard Estrada

  2. Tripped Up

    Help! Where Is the Safest Seat on an Airplane?

    Deciding where to sit on a plane has always been an exercise in strategy and skill: how to get the most legroom, the best shut-eye, the quickest exit. The stakes certainly feel higher now.

    1d agoBy Sarah Firshein

  2. Holiday Travel and Safety: 5 Things We Know

    During the current pandemic surge, how risky is it to travel during what is normally one of the busiest seasons? And how is the industry making it safer? Here’s what you need to know.

    2d agoBy Elaine Glusac

  3. Should I Travel This Year?

    Travel looks very different in 2020. Here are some questions to help you consider the risks to yourself and others if you take a trip.

    October 30, 2020By Sara Aridi and Umi Syam

The New World of Travel

  1. The Future of Travel

    Perhaps no industry has been as hard hit by the pandemic as tourism. As restrictions on companies and travelers ease, what will the new world look like?

    September 10, 2020By Elaine Glusac, Tariro Mzezewa and Sarah Firshein

  4. Where Cruise Ships Are Sent to Die

    At a shipyard in Turkey, the boats, including some from Carnival’s Fantasy fleet, are being turned into scrap, even as the industry hopes to find a way to start sailing.

    October 30, 2020By Ceylan Yeginsu

  5. How to Staycation in 6 American Cities

    1d agoBy Elaine Glusac

  2. Help! I’d Like to Ride the Train. Is it Safe?

    Our columnist finds that rail companies, both regional systems and Amtrak, are undertaking major coronavirus efforts. But they can’t thoroughly disinfect every seat in every train at every station.

    October 5, 2020By Sarah Firshein

    Many American citizens were traveling internationally when the pandemic struck. For those who have no interest in coming home in the short-term, but face expiring tourist visas, our columnist investigates the options.

    August 12, 2020By Sarah Firshein
